back:
For \(m \times n\) matrices \(\mathbf{A}\) and
\(\mathbf{B}\), the sum \( \mathbf{A} + \mathbf{B}\) is defined as the
elementwise sum:
\begin{equation*} \mathbf{A} + \mathbf{B} = \begin{bmatrix} a_{0,0} + b_{0,0}  & a_{0,1} + b_{0,1} & \ldots & a_{0,n-1} + b_{0,n-1}  \\ a_{1,0} + b_{1,0}  & a_{1,1} + b_{1,1} & \ldots & a_{1,n-1} + b_{0,n-1}  \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ldots & \vdots \\ a_{m-1,0} + b_{m-1,0}  & a_{m-1,1} + b_{m-1,1} & \ldots & a_{m-1,n-1} + b_{m-1,n-1}  \\ \end{bmatrix}. \end{equation*}

For a matrix $\mathbf{A}$ and a scalar $c$, the product $c \mathbf{A} = \mathbf{A}c$ is defined as the matrix whose entries are the product of $c$ and the corresponding entries of $\mathbf{A}$:\begin{equation*} c \mathbf{A} = \begin{bmatrix} c a_{0,0} & c a_{0,1} & \ldots & c a_{0,n-1} \\ c a_{1,0} & c a_{1,1} & \ldots & c a_{1,n-1} \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ldots & \vdots \\ c a_{m-1,0} & c a_{m-1,1} & \ldots & c a_{m-1,n-1} \\ \end{bmatrix}. \end{equation*}

For an $p \times q$ matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) and a $q \times 1$ vector \(\mathbf{u}\), the product \(\mathbf{M} \mathbf{u}\) is the $p \times 1$ vector of dot products of the rows of $\mathbf{M}$ with the vector $\mathbf{u}$ given by\begin{align*} \begin{bmatrix} \mathbf{m_{0\ast}}\cdot \mathbf{u} \\ \mathbf{m_{1\ast}} \cdot \mathbf{u}\\ \vdots \\ \mathbf{m_{p-1\ast}}\cdot \mathbf{u}\\ \end{bmatrix}, \end{align*} where $\mathbf{m_{i\ast}}$ is the $i$th row of $\mathbf{M}$.

For an $p \times q$ matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) and a $q \times 1$ vector \(\mathbf{u}\), the product \(\mathbf{M} \mathbf{u}\) is the $p \times 1$ vector \begin{equation*} \begin{bmatrix} u_0\underset{|}{\overset{|}{\mathbf{m}_0}}   &+&  u_1\underset{|}{\overset{|}{\mathbf{m}_1}} &+& \ldots &+& u_{q-1} \!\!\!\!\!\underset{|}{\overset{|}{\,\,\,\,\,\,\mathbf{m}_{q-1}}} \end{bmatrix}^, \end{equation*} where $\mathbf{m}_i$ is the $i$th column of $\mathbf{M}$.

The process of creating new features from raw data,
  often with the intent of reducing the number of features.
